text: And Abram said to the king of Sodom, I have lift up mine hand unto the LORD, the most high God, the possessor of heaven and earth,
text_kjv: And Abram said to the king of Sodom, I have lift up mine hand unto the LORD, the most high God, the possessor of heaven and earth,
text_niv: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, “I have raised my hand to the Lord, God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth, and have taken an oath
text_esv: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, “I have lifted my hand  to the LORD, God Most High, Possessor of heaven and earth,
text_nlt: Abram replied to the king of Sodom, “I solemnly swear to the LORD, God Most High, Creator of heaven and earth,
text_msg: But Abram told the king of Sodom, "I swear to God, The High God, Creator of Heaven and Earth, this solemn oath,
text_nasb: Abram said to the king of Sodom, 'I have sworn to the LORD God Most High, possessor of heaven and earth,
context: Genesis 14 occurs within the patriarchal narratives, depicting Abram's journey of faith. This chapter specifically details a military conflict between several kings in the region of Canaan and the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah, among others. Sodom is defeated, and its people and possessions are taken captive, including Lot, Abram's nephew. Upon learning this, Abram swiftly gathers his trained fighting men (318 in total) born in his own house and pursues the victorious armies, defeating them and recovering the captives and goods. The king of Sodom then approaches Abram, offering him the recovered goods, likely as compensation for his efforts. However, Abram refuses the offer, making the declaration in verse 22. Understanding the geopolitics of the time is crucial. Kings often formed alliances and offered tribute. Abram's refusal to accept spoils from the king of Sodom, a city known for its wickedness, was a highly unusual act. This refusal wasn't simply a rejection of personal gain; it was a public declaration of his allegiance to God and a rejection of any association with the corrupt values of Sodom. Lifting up the hand was a common ancient Near Eastern gesture signifying an oath or a solemn promise, made publicly and witnessed by others. The phrase 'the most high God, the possessor of heaven and earth' uses titles that reflect a broader understanding of God beyond the local deities worshipped in Canaan, highlighting the universality of God's dominion.
meaning: Abram's statement is profoundly theological. By lifting his hand to the Lord, he is enacting a formal oath, making a solemn vow before God and the king of Sodom. His refusal of the king of Sodom's offer stems from his deeper commitment to God as the source of all blessings. Abram recognizes God as 'the most high God' (El Elyon), a title emphasizing God's supreme authority and power over all. This acknowledgement contrasts sharply with the polytheistic beliefs prevalent at the time. It proclaims that Yahweh is above all other gods or rulers. Furthermore, defining God as 'the possessor of heaven and earth' (Koneh Shamayim va'aretz) underscores God's ownership and control over all creation. This implies that God is the ultimate source of wealth and provision, not the king of Sodom. Abram understands that true prosperity comes from God's blessing, not from worldly spoils that could compromise his integrity. Therefore, accepting the goods would implicitly acknowledge the king of Sodom as the provider, diminishing God's role. This declaration reveals Abram's understanding of covenant theology. He is choosing to remain faithful to God's promise and to avoid entanglement with the corrupt values of Sodom. By rejecting the spoils, Abram affirms his reliance on God's faithfulness to fulfill His promises, ultimately foreshadowing the inheritance he will receive through God's covenant, a land infinitely more valuable than any earthly reward offered by a sinful king.
application: In modern life, Abram's declaration provides a powerful example of prioritizing spiritual integrity over material gain. We are constantly faced with choices that test our values, from ethical dilemmas in the workplace to temptations to compromise our beliefs for personal advancement. Abram's refusal of the king of Sodom's offer challenges us to examine our own motivations and allegiances. Are we willing to sacrifice short-term benefits for long-term spiritual rewards? It calls for discernment in our relationships and associations. Just as Abram refused to be indebted to the king of Sodom, we should be cautious about forming alliances or accepting favors that could compromise our values or lead us astray. This doesn't mean isolating ourselves, but rather being discerning about the influences we allow into our lives. Moreover, Abram's statement reminds us that God is the ultimate source of provision and blessing. In a society that often emphasizes self-reliance and material wealth, it's easy to lose sight of God's role in our lives. We must regularly acknowledge God as 'the possessor of heaven and earth' and trust in His faithfulness to provide for our needs. This requires cultivating a spirit of gratitude and generosity, recognizing that all we have comes from God. It also calls for us to use our resources wisely and to be generous to those in need, reflecting God's character in our actions. Finally, we must remain steadfast in our commitment to God, even when faced with opposition or temptation. Like Abram, we may encounter situations where choosing the right path is difficult or unpopular. But by lifting our hands to the Lord, affirming our allegiance to Him, and trusting in His promises, we can overcome these challenges and live lives that honor God.
prayer: Most High God, possessor of heaven and earth, I lift my heart to you. Forgive me for the times I've sought provision and security in things other than you. Help me to have the discernment to recognize the allure of worldly gain that could compromise my integrity. Grant me the courage to stand firm in my faith, even when it's difficult. Remind me daily that you are the source of all blessings and that true wealth lies in a relationship with you. Fill me with gratitude for your constant provision and guide me to use my resources to honor you and bless others. I dedicate my life to you, trusting in your unfailing love and promises. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Abram refused the spoils to avoid any suggestion that the King of Sodom had made him rich, thus ensuring that God alone received the glory for his prosperity and victory. He didn't want to compromise his allegiance to God.

faqs.answer: Abram's giving of tithes to Melchizedek is often seen as an early example of honoring God with one's possessions and acknowledging God as the source of all blessings, a principle later formalized in the Mosaic Law.
